item.title: City Sales & Use Tax Revenue for February
item.description:
Mayor Dewey F. Bartlett Jr. said today that the City of Tulsa's February sales tax revenue for mid-December 2013 to mid-January 2014, as reported by the Oklahoma Tax Commission, totaled $21,026,499, which is up 2 percent from last year and 2.9 percent below budget estimates. Year-to-date sales tax collections are up 0.7 percent for this fiscal year compared to last fiscal year.

Holiday sales are reflected in the January and February checks the City received. In the general fund, sales tax collections for the two months were expected to grow by 2.8 percent from last year's $26 million level, but instead fell by 0.6 percent leaving a $ 900,000 shortfall against budget expectations.

"In spring of 2013, the economic indicators initially supported a 3 percent sales tax growth for FY 14. However, the reality is the local economy has shown signs of softness," said Finance Director Mike Kier. "Buyer habits are changing as consumers are using credit less and saving more and buying goods online from out-of-state retailers that do not collect state or city sales taxes. Tulsa is losing approximately $10 million in sales this year due to tax-free internet sales."

Use tax revenues totaled $2,744,807, which is up 30 percent from the same period a year ago, and 24 percent above budget estimates for the month. Year-to-date use tax collections are up 13.2 percent for this fiscal year compared to last fiscal year, and 8.5 percent above the year-to-date budget estimate.

"With softening sales tax collections in the current economy, we must face the likelihood that the City of Tulsa's sales tax reimbursement will stay somewhat flat moving forward," Mayor Dewey Bartlett said. "We must remain prudent in our budgetary decisions and find long-term solutions to provide core services to the citizens of Tulsa."

item.title: Tulsa Police Officer, Tulsa Firefighter Receive Above & Beyond Award
item.description:
Founded in 2008, the Rotary Club of Tulsa's Above and Beyond Awards recognize Tulsa's police officer and firefighter of the year. The event acknowledges these public servants for outstanding acts of character, commitment and compassion to both their profession and community. 

Nominated by their peers, the award recipients have gone "Above and Beyond" by serving their communities and exemplifying the values reflected in the Rotary Four-Way Test.  Award nominations were provided by each respective department and recipients were selected by a committee of the Rotary Club of Tulsa.

Police Officer of the Year - Detective Elizabeth Eagan

A 31-year veteran of the Tulsa Police Department, Detective Elizabeth Eagan has spent the last 11 years working in the Sex Crimes Unit as an unrelenting and tenacious officer who pursues justice for individuals that have been victims of horrific crimes. 

When not protecting our community's most vulnerable citizens, Detective Eagan is an active volunteer of Going Home Animal Rescue & Transport, an organization that transports animals between rescue groups and municipal shelters that are at over capacity so that animals may have an opportunity to become an adoptable pet.

Detective Eagan has contributed hundreds of hours to care for neglected animals and has transported many of them across the country to locations such as Denver, Chicago and Cincinnati. Eagan also volunteered to rescue and transport animals that were lost and abandoned due to the fatal tornado in Moore, Okla.

Eagan's dedication of service to both her profession and volunteer efforts will have a positive and lasting impact on those touched by her work.

TPD nominated Detective Eagan for the Rotary Club of Tulsa's Above and Beyond Award. The Rotary Club of Tulsa will honor Detective Eagan with a $1,000 donation to the Going Home Animal Rescue & Transport organization.

Firefighter of the Year - Raymond Beard

A 13 year veteran of the Tulsa Fire Department and driver for Station 22, Raymond Beard embodies the meaning of 'service above self'. In addition to protecting and serving Tulsa citizens as a dedicated firefighter, Beard is a dedicated and active member of the East Virgin Street Church of Christ.  

When Beard learned that a fellow church member was in search of a kidney donor, he volunteered to undergo the necessary testing to determine if he could be a compatible match. 

After lab results indicated that Beard was indeed a donor match, he without hesitation and selflessly volunteered to donate his kidney to the congregation member. Beard used his allotted sick leave and vacation time from work so that he could donate his kidney and provide the gift of life to another human being.

Beard risks his life daily to protect and save the property and lives of Tulsans. The act of donating his kidney to an individual in need exemplifies the true spirit of going above and beyond.

Beard was nominated by a leader of TFD for the Rotary Club of Tulsa's Above and Beyond Award. The Rotary Club will donate $1,000 to the Tulsa Youth Athletic Association.

item.title: Use Tax Vital to Tulsa
item.description:
As Tulsans begin filing their 2013 income tax returns, they need to remember that they are required to pay use tax on their online purchases from retailers without a presence in the state of Oklahoma. The City of Tulsa receives use tax as a proportion of what is paid to the state.

Sales tax and use tax collections provide two-thirds of the City of Tulsa's revenue. Vital services such as police and fire protection, 911 emergency dispatch, snow and ice removal from streets, pothole repair and mowing of grass in medians and parks are supported by sales and use taxes.

Use tax is the same amount as sales tax - in Tulsa it's 8.517 percent - but it is paid on out-of-state purchases that were not taxed at the point of sale. State tax forms explain how to calculate the tax or estimate it if taxpayers don't remember what they bought online. It's entered on line 20 of the tax forms.

The City of Tulsa Finance Department estimates that the City would have $10 million more per year if Tulsa residents paid the use taxes they owe. Currently 97 percent of Oklahoma taxpayers ignore the use tax, which relies on the honor system because federal law does not require online retailers to collect the tax for states, cities and counties.

item.title: TARE Takes Action on City's Curbside Greenwaste Program
item.description:
The Tulsa Authority for Recovery of Energy (TARE)  voted on a variety of items related to the City's curbside greenwaste program.

TARE members voted to suspend the greenwaste sticker requirement until further notice. Members stated they would revisit the matter after an enhanced greenwaste program is in place.

Residents can continue to leave their greenwaste at the curb in 2ft. across and 4 ft. long bundles or in clear plastic bags without a greenwaste sticker.

TARE also moved forward to have staff work with consultant Leidos, to draft a request for proposals (RFP) to pursue bids for the curbside greenwaste program. Refuse and recycling services are contracted.

The RFP for the greenwaste service would be a short-term solution that would give TARE time to get a modified greenwaste program in place that would implement long-term solutions. Staff reported they expect to present the RFP for TARE's approval in February. TARE has the ability to choose whether to accept or not accept a proposal.

"The short-term solution of accepting a proposal on the curbside greenwaste service will help the City bridge the gap from where we are now with greenwaste to where we want to be in the future with an economically feasible and operationally manageable program," TARE Vice-Chair Paul White said. "Not only would contracting greenwaste service save a substantial amount of money in the interim, but gives TARE the opportunity to evaluate the long-term solutions recommended by the citizen/council taskforce and address operational issues before a modified greenwaste program is adopted."

The TARE Board also voted to continue a contract with QuikTrip to sell the orange refuse stickers, which are required for additional refuse that cannot fit in the refuse cart.

item.title: Street Project to Resume on W. 71st St. near Arkansas River
item.description:
Construction of a street rehabilitation project on West 71st Street near the Arkansas River will resume on Tuesday, Jan. 21. Traffic will be limited to one eastbound lane and one westbound lane until completion of the project in April.

This work is part of a larger project that includes street rehabilitation on West 71st Street between U.S. Highway 75 and the Arkansas River bridge. The City of Tulsa has contracted with APAC Central Inc. for this $2.9 million project funded by the 2008 General Obligation Bond Issue.

Lane closures and street work on this project had stopped during the recent holiday season. During that time, the contractor worked on sidewalks, to minimize traffic disruptions.

item.title: Fix Our Streets Sales Tax Rebate Available One More Time
item.description:
This is the fourth and final year that $25 sales tax rebates will be available from the 2008 Fix Our Streets package. Rebates will be distributed in 2014 according to eligibility in 2013.

Residents must submit applications to the City of Tulsa to receive a rebate. Applications for the 2013 rebate are due by April 15, 2014.

Tulsa residents may qualify for rebates either by age - 65 years or older for any part of 2013 - or income through eligibility for the Oklahoma Sales Tax Refund or Oklahoma Earned Income Tax Credit. It is recommended that residents who qualify both by age and income use age as their eligibility for faster processing.

Other requirements for the rebate:

  • Recipient must have lived in the Tulsa city limits for at least one year prior to application.
  • Recipient must be the family member who contributed the greatest share of income for his or her household.
  • Rebates are limited to one per household.

Residents can obtain forms in several ways, including:

  • At City Hall, 175 E. 2nd St. - Street Level Customer Service Cashier and City Clerk
  • By request from the Customer Care Center, (918) 596-2100
  • Online

The City of Tulsa will send rebates to recipients after the Oklahoma Department of Public Safety has verified age eligibility and/or the Oklahoma Tax Commission has verified income eligibility. This process will begin after the April 15 tax filing deadline and will take several months beyond that. Some Tulsa residents may not receive their rebates until the fall of 2014.

item.title: 61st Street Closing for Sewer Line Replacement
item.description:
Sixty-first Street between South Rockford and South Yorktown will be closed for five to six months, while Crossland Heavy Construction, a City contractor, replaces a large sanitary sewer line that lies beneath the street . 

The closure begins  Monday, Nov. 25, 2013.

 Local traffic will be directed to the access road along the north side of 61st. Several neighborhood streets will no longer have access to 61st during the project. Alternate neighborhood routes will be marked with temporary signs.

Four lanes of traffic are open on West 71st Street between U.S. Highway 75 and the Arkansas River, as of 5 p.m. Friday, Nov. 1. The speed limit also has changed back to 45 miles per hour.

During the holiday season, the contractor will work on sidewalks. Some work on the project remains to be completed on West 71st Street near the Arkansas River. In January 2014, street work and lane closures will resume at that location, with completion of the project scheduled for April 2014.

Street rehabilitation on West 71st Street between U.S. 75 and the Arkansas River has been in progress since January. The City of Tulsa has contracted with APAC Central for this $2.9 million Fix Our Streets project, funded by the 2008 General Obligation Bond Issue.

item.title: Tulsa Water Maintains High Quality
item.description:
The City of Tulsa's 2013 Customer Confidence Report (CCR) reports that the City's system continues to deliver high quality, good-tasting water that is safe to drink and free of bacteria.

The CCR is an annual water quality report required to be mailed to all water customers under the provisions of the federal 1996 Safe Drinking Water Act and its amendments. The City samples and analyzes its treated drinking water throughout the year to make sure it meets or exceeds federal standards.

The report concluded that tests conducted on treated water during 2012 showed that the levels of all contaminants continued to fall below the regulatory levels prescribed by the Environmental Protection Agency.

The CCR is included with the June utility bills mailed to customers within the City of Tulsa and is also provided to municipal water systems that purchase water from Tulsa. Anyone who does not receive a copy and wishes to see one can request it from the City of Tulsa's Customer Care Center by calling (918) 596-2100 or by email to mac@cityoftulsa.org .  The water quality report can also be viewed online at www.tulsawater.com The CCR is also available in Spanish.

The City of Tulsa Water and Sewer Department operates two water treatment plants that receive water from Lake Oologah, Lakes Spavinaw and Eucha and Lake Hudson. Water samples from the lakes also are analyzed to determine source water quality. Water and sewer operations and policies are overseen by a volunteer body, the Tulsa Metropolitan Utility Authority. The CCR also provides information about the TMUA and its meeting schedule. Online information about the TMUA is available at www.tulsawater.com

item.title: Boulder Avenue Bridge Artwork Lighted at Night
item.description:
A dynamic light display to show off the artwork on the downtown Boulder Avenue bridge has begun and continues nightly from sunset to sunrise.

Each night at sunset, all of the artwork across the bridge will be lighted with a bluish-white solid light for seven minutes. This will be followed by an eight-minute, multi-color dynamic display. The 15-minute cycle will continue all night until sunrise.

The dynamic light display will move across the bridge from the south side to the north side. It will begin as dark blue, fading into a yellow-red sunrise, followed by a white spotlight. The white spotlight will fade into an orange-pink sunset, and then the dark blue will reappear.

Special lighting is planned for a few holidays during the year. The first will be red, white and blue lighting for July 3, 4, and 5 to celebrate Independence Day. Throughout the month of December, the artwork will be lighted in red and green. Green lighting is planned for next year's St. Patrick's Day on March 17.

item.title: City Earns Third 'A+' Grade in a Row from Sunshine Review
item.description:
Mayor Dewey Bartlett announced today that the City of Tulsa has received a grade of A+ from the Sunshine Review for transparency in government on the City's website for the third consecutive year. Tulsa is among an elite group of 250 government entities in the United States that received an "A+" for full disclosure of online government information.

"Accountability of government is vitally important to citizens and our efforts to inform and educate citizens through our website is one way we build relationships and earn taxpayer confidence," Mayor Bartlett said. "We work to update the city's website, provide informational videos about our programs and services and share information through social media sites to increase awareness and keep citizens engaged in city government."

The Sunshine Review, a nonprofit organization dedicated to state and local government transparency, announces the annual awards during Sunshine Week, held nationwide this year March 10-16. Sunshine Week is a period nationally recognized by media and civic organizations to celebrate strides taken toward open government.

For the 2013 awards, the Sunshine Review analyzed more than 1,000 qualifying government websites and graded each on a 10-Point Transparency Checklist. The checklist included items such as budgets, meetings, lobbying, financial audits, contracts, public records and taxes.

Citizens can find the following information and more on the City of Tulsa website (www.cityoftulsa.org): current permits, monthly commercial and residential permits, financial reports, Grants Consolidated Annual Performance and Evaluation Report (CAPER), internal audits, meeting agendas, collective bargaining agreements, ADA Self-Evaluation and Transition Plan, city charter, ordinances and executive orders and lists of authorities, boards and commissions.

To view the City of Tulsa's Sunshine Report, visit: http://sunshinereview.org/index.php/Tulsa,_Oklahoma.

To view the Sunshine Report scores across the nation and for more information about the Sunshine Review, visit: http://sunshinereview.org.

The Sunshine Review, a nonprofit organization dedicated to state and local government transparency, announces the annual awards during Sunshine Week, held nationwide this year March 10-16. Sunshine Week is a period nationally recognized by media and civic organizations to celebrate strides taken toward open government.

For the 2013 awards, the Sunshine Review analyzed more than 1,000 qualifying government websites and graded each on a 10-Point Transparency Checklist. The checklist included items such as budgets, meetings, lobbying, financial audits, contracts, public records and taxes.

Citizens can find the following information and more on the City of Tulsa website (www.cityoftulsa.org): current permits, monthly commercial and residential permits, financial reports, Grants Consolidated Annual Performance and Evaluation Report (CAPER), internal audits, meeting agendas, collective bargaining agreements, ADA Self-Evaluation and Transition Plan, city charter, ordinances and executive orders and lists of authorities, boards and commissions.

To view the City of Tulsa's Sunshine Report, visit: http://sunshinereview.org/index.php/Tulsa,_Oklahoma.

To view the Sunshine Report scores across the nation and for more information about the Sunshine Review, visit: http://sunshinereview.org.
